# Step 2 - NPM

At the moment, our application uses [Bootstrap 5](https://getbootstrap.com/) imported from [Bootstrap CDN](https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/bootstrap@5.0.0-beta3/dist/css/bootstrap.css), and pasted as a copy to `front-end/src/app/styles/bootstrap.css`.

This is a really bad practise to copy-paste in our project code that comes from external libraries:

- It increases the size of your repository.
- It looses track of the version of the library
- libraries should be updated one by one, by hand.

In this step, we leverage **NPM package manager** to manage our project and install dependencies.

> ![info] With a package manager, it comes easier to add new libraries, and update existing ones.

## Step 2.1 - Init a new package

A project that uses NPM is called a _package_, and is described by the file `package.json`. Before we use NPM to download dependencies, we must generate the `package.json` file.

**Your job**:

- Create a new NPM package:

  ```bash
  cd front-end/
  npm init
  ```

  > ![info] You can also use [yarn](https://yarnpkg.com/en) as slightly faster alternative to NPM.

- When prompted, call the package and call it `@{your-name}/meme-ory` (replace `{your-name}` with your name).
  You can leave other prompts with default values. Check the generated `package.json`

```json
{
  "name": "Meme-ory",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "",
  "dependencies": {},
  "devDependencies": {},
  "scripts": {
    "test": "echo \"Error: no test specified\" && exit 1"
  },
  "author": "Takima",
  "license": "MIT"
}
```

> ![info] NPM is initially made for node projects. As a result, you will be asked to set an entrypoint. Because we write a Browser application and not a NodeJS application, you can leave `entrypoint` with a blank value.

> ![info] `package.json` is the file descriptor for an NPM package. Learn more about this with the [official documentation](https://docs.npmjs.com/files/package.json).

- Make your package private:

  ```javascript
  //package.json
  {
    ...
    "private": true,
    ...
  }
  ```

  > ![tip] Marking a package as private to avoid publishing it to npmjs.com by accident.

> ![question] As you can see, `npm install` command also generated a `package-lock.json` file along with `package.json`. What is the purpose of this file?

#### Files produced:

```
package.json
package-lock.json
node_modules/
```

**![commit] commit step**

## Step 2.2 - Install bootstrap

Now that we have a package manager, we can use it to install **bootstrap 5**

**Your job**:

- Install bootstrap;

  ```bash
  cd front-end
  npm install bootstrap@next
  ```

  Notice how your `package.json` have been updated with the _dependencies_:

  ```json
  // front-end/package.json
  {
    // ...
    "dependencies": {
      "bootstrap": "^5.0.0-beta3"
    }
  }
  ```

  > ![question] [By convention](https://docs.npmjs.com/about-semantic-versioning/), all NPM dependencies use a 3-digit format for version numbers. How do you call this?
  > Can you explain the meaning of the `^` symbol next to the bootstrap version?

  > ![tip] Avoid editing `package.json` by yourself. Everytime you need to update it, use an `npm` command instead.

- In the meantime, NPM created a **`node_modules`** folder, where it put all the downloaded dependencies.
  Locate `front-end/node_modules/bootstrap/` folder to double check it has been properly installed.

  > ![tip] `node_module` contains tons of code from your libraries. Do not forget to ignore this directory within your `.gitignore`.

- Search for the `<!-- TODO Step 2.1 -->` comments to track references to `styles/bootstrap.css`, and replace them to point toward `node_modules/dist/css/bootstrap.css` instead.
- `styles/bootstrap.css` should not be used anymore by now. Delete this file.

#### Checklist:

- [ ] I deleted the copied `styles/bootstrap.css`
- [ ] I know how to init a new NPM package
- [ ] I can install an NPM dependency
- [ ] My application uses bootstrap from `node_modules/`
- [ ] There is no `TODO Step 2.1` in my code anymore

**![commit] commit step**

## Step 2.3 - NPM scripts

Did you notice the generated `package.json` has a `"scripts"` section ?

```json
// front-end/package.json
{
  "name": "@nthierion/meme-ory",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "",
  "main": "index.js",
  "scripts": {
    // <============== HERE!!
    "test": "echo \"Error: no test specified\" && exit 1"
  },
  "author": "",
  "license": "ISC",
  "dependencies": {
    "bootstrap": "^5.0.0-beta3"
  }
}
```

The `"scripts"` configuration allows developers write custom scripts needed to build/run/test the project.

At the moment, only the `"test"` script is available. You can run it with the following command

```bash
npm run test
```

Of course, this script fails because we did not configure any tests, so you can just delete this script.

> ![tip] Large JS projects sometimes require a lot of complex commands to build the project. In such case, consider creating an NPM script, as you won't have to remember these commands. `scripts` also serve as a documentation for other developers.

In the setup step, we did launch our project with the following command:

```bash
npx http-server -c-1
```

In this step, we create a `script` for this command/

**Your job:**

- install the `http-server` as a dev dependency for our project.

  ```bash
  npm install -D http-server
  ```

  > ![info] the `-D` parameter in `npm install -D` installs `http-server` as a **devDependency** rather **dependency**. Look at `package.json` to see how it changes.

  > ![question] What is a `devDependency` exactly? What are the differences with a `depencency`?

- Add a new script called `start`, that cranks-up the `http-server`:

  ```json
  // front-end/package.json
  {
    "scripts": {
      "start": "http-server -c-1"
    }
  }
  ```

- Kill `http-server` if it has been launched previously. Now, you can just start your application with the following command:

  ```bash
  npm start
  ```

  > ![info] Nearly all projects supports `npm run (start|test)` command.

#### Checklist

- [ ] I know what _npm scripts_ are
- [ ] I can run my application with `npm start` command
- [ ] I understand the differences between _dependencies_ and _devDependencies_

**![commit] commit step**
